content: The list of independent counsels appointed by the special Division of the Court for Appointing Independent Counsels includes names, areas of investigation, results, and cost information. This information is derived from audits by the Government Accountability Office and Senate Committee reports. The list of independent counsels and special prosecutors includes those appointed by the Special Division of the Court, with some identities kept confidential. Under federal law, information on appointments and investigation targets was generally confidential. There have been 20 investigations initiated under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978, with total costs reported by the Department of Justice and Government Accountability Office audits. Independent counsel investigations and audits from the Government Accountability Office have cost approximately $228,712,589 as of September 30, 2005. The statutory provisions for independent counsels expired in 1999, but special counsels can still be appointed by the Attorney General. Separate cost figures have been released for special counsel investigations. The Government Accountability Office reported that various investigations, including those by Robert Fiske and John Danforth, have incurred significant costs. Patrick Fitzgerald was designated as a Special Counsel to investigate the unauthorized disclosure of a CIA employee's identity, with expenses totaling $902,118 as of September 31, 2005. Results of Independent Counsel Investigations show that out of 20 cases initiated, 12 resulted in no indictments. In 8 cases with indictments, 3 did not involve the principal Government official initially targeted. Of the 5 cases where officials were indicted, 3 were acquitted or had their convictions overturned. Despite multiple convictions, only two named federal officials were convicted in independent counsel investigations. Only two federal officials were convicted or pleaded guilty in the 20 independent counsel investigations. In one case, presidential aide Michael Deaver was convicted of perjury, while in another case, Secretary Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge. Special prosecutors appointed under federal law have investigated various allegations, with some cases resulting in no criminal charges. Special prosecutors investigated allegations involving high-profile figures like Tim Kraft and Raymond J. Donovan, with costs ranging from $3,300 to $318,000. Despite investigations, no prosecutions were warranted, and no indictments were sought in subsequent investigations. Jacob A. Stein investigated allegations regarding Edwin Meese, finding no basis for criminal charges. The investigation cost $312,000. Alexia Morrison investigated allegations against Theodore B. Olson, finding insufficient evidence of false statements or obstruction of justice. The investigation cost $2,141,000. Whitney North Seymour Jr. investigated charges against Michael K. Deaver for violating conflict of interest laws. Deaver was convicted of perjury and sentenced to probation and a fine. Lawrence E. Walsh was appointed to investigate Lt. Colonel Oliver North and others in the Iran-Contra matter. Several individuals pleaded guilty to offenses related to the case. Several individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair were convicted of federal offenses, including Lt. Col. Oliver North, National Security Advisor John M. Poindexter, and others. Some convictions were overturned due to immunized congressional testimony being used against them. Court ruling found that immunized congressional testimony was used against individuals involved in the Iran-Contra affair, leading to tainted convictions. Indicted persons included Duane Clarridge, Joseph F. Fernandez, and Casper Weinberger. President George Bush pardoned Weinberger and Clarridge, along with others involved in the scandal. The Independent Counsel's final report on the Iran-Contra matter was filed in August 1993, with the investigation costing $47,873,400. James C. McKay was appointed to investigate allegations related to Franklyn C. Nofziger and potential conflicts of interest. The Independent Counsel investigated conflicts of interest and alleged influence peddling involving Attorney General Edwin Meese and the Wedtech Corporation. The report concluded that while some of Meese's conduct may have violated criminal law, no prosecution was warranted. Nofziger was convicted but the conviction was overturned on appeal. The final report was filed in July 1988. The Independent Counsel investigated various cases involving government officials, with costs ranging from $15,000 to $2,796,000. One investigation focused on allegations of criminal conspiracy to defraud the United States, but no indictments were sought. Another investigation looked into conflicts of interest and influence peddling, resulting in no prosecution. The Independent Counsel investigated cases involving government officials, including corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Several individuals were found guilty of bribery, conspiracy, and money laundering. Several government officials, including Catalina Vasquez Villalpando, Deborah Gore Dean, Thomas Demery, Robert B. Olsen, Philip D. Winn, Leonard Briscoe, Maurice Steier, and Lance H., were found guilty of various charges related to bribery, conspiracy, and obstruction of justice in connection with the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Several individuals, including private businessman Leonard Briscoe, Omaha attorney Maurice Steier, and former HUD official Lance H. Wilson, were convicted of offering illegal gratuities to a HUD official. Other guilty parties included Elaine Richardson, Silvio J. DeBartolomeis, Benton Mortgage Company, Samuel P. Singletary, and James G. Watt, each involved in various fraudulent activities related to HUD funding. Former HUD Assistant Secretary Philip D. Winn, who pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges, was pardoned by President Clinton. The independent counsel's final report was released in October 1998, with the investigation costing $29,417,318. Michael F. Zeldin succeeded Joseph E. diGenova to investigate potential violations of federal law regarding the search of Bill Clinton's passport files during the 1992 presidential campaign. The final investigative report by Counsel diGenova found no evidence warranting criminal prosecution related to the search of William Clinton's passport files. The investigation cost $3,089,082. Julie F. Thomas succeeded Robert W. Ray in March 2002, continuing the investigation initiated by Independent Counsel Kenneth W. Starr regarding Whitewater allegations. Independent Counsel Starr's jurisdiction was expanded in March 1996. The jurisdiction of Independent Counsel Starr was expanded multiple times to investigate various matters involving the White House, including the firing of staff, misuse of FBI files, false statements, and allegations of perjury and obstruction of justice. Several individuals have pleaded guilty or been convicted as a result of these investigations. Several individuals, including James McDougal, Susan McDougal, Jim Guy Tucker, Webster L. Hubbell, Suzanna Hubbell, Michael C. Schaufele, and Charles C. Owen, were indicted for failure to pay federal income taxes. Webster Hubbell faced additional charges for concealing and making false statements about land deals in Arkansas. Hubbell pleaded guilty to tax evasion and false statements, resulting in dropped charges for the other individuals involved. The April 30, 1998 indictment charges were dropped in a plea agreement. Other outcomes of the investigation included acquittals for various individuals and mistrials for Julie Hyatt Steele and Susan McDougal. Independent Counsel Starr stated on May 25, 1999 that no retrials would occur for the hung-jury counts. The "Whitewater aspect" of the Clintons' investigation was concluded with no further indictments. Independent Counsel Ray confirmed on September 20, 2000, that there would be no indictments for President or First Lady Clinton in the "Whitewater" matter. Reports issued to the court found no evidence of criminal conduct involving them. On January 19, 2001, Independent Counsel Ray declined prosecution in the Monica Lewinsky and Paula Jones-deposition matter, with President Clinton admitting to giving evasive answers in the Jones civil suit deposition. He agreed to a five-year law license suspension and a $25,000 fine. President Clinton pardoned four individuals involved in the Arkansas "Whitewater" investigation. Independent Counsel Starr submitted reports reaffirming findings on Vincent Foster's death and information possibly leading to impeachment. The investigation costs totaled $73,597,345. Donald C. Smaltz was appointed to investigate potential criminal conduct involving gifts received by Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy. The investigations resulted in guilty pleas, fines, and settlements from various individuals and companies. Several individuals and companies were convicted or fined for providing gifts, gratuities, and campaign contributions to Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy, including Oglethorpe Power Corp., Robert Mondavi Corporation, Tysons Foods, Sun-Diamond Growers, John Hemmingson, Alverez Ferrouillet Jr., Ronald H. Blackley, and others. Several individuals and companies were convicted or fined for providing gifts, gratuities, and campaign contributions to Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy, including Jack L. Williams, lobbyist for Tyson Foods, Inc., Richard Douglas, former Senior Vice President of Sun-Diamond Growers, and Archibald R. Schaffer. Acquitted individuals include John J. Hemmingson, Gary Black, and Henry Espy, Jr., brother of Mike Espy. Former Secretary Mike Espy was acquitted of conspiracy and concealing illegal campaign contributions, along with Norris Faust, Jr. of the Farm Service Agency who was acquitted of perjury. Several individuals convicted in connection with the investigation were pardoned by President Clinton. Independent Counsel Smaltz's final report was filed in 2001, with investigations costing over $25 million. David M. Barrett was appointed to investigate allegations against Department of Housing and Urban Development Secretary Henry G. Cisneros. Former Secretary Henry G. Cisneros was indicted on false statement charges, along with Linda Jones and two former aides. Charges against the aides were dropped, while Jones pleaded guilty to multiple felony counts. Cisneros pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge and was fined. He and Jones were pardoned by President Clinton in 2001. The Special Division of the Court of Appeals decided not to terminate the office of Independent Counsel Barrett, instructing him to continue noninvestigative tasks. The final report was filed in 2004, with a cost of $24,438,915. Daniel S. Pearson was appointed as independent counsel to investigate financial dealings of Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, with a cost of $3,861,710. Curtis E. von Kann was appointed to investigate conflict of interest violations, with no indictments returned. Carol Elder Bruce was appointed to investigate false statements to Congress by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt regarding a proposed Indian gambling casino in Wisconsin. No criminal indictments were sought, and the final report was filed in December 1999. The investigation cost $7,152,293. Ralph I. Lancaster was appointed to investigate unlawful solicitation of campaign contributions by Secretary of Labor, Alexis Herman. Only one indictment was made against a Singapore businessman for illegal campaign contributions. The final report was submitted in April 2000. The investigation into false statements by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt regarding a proposed Indian gambling casino in Wisconsin cost $6,027,860 as of September 30, 2005.
